column1: These cells are part of the retina (the back part of the eye).
An electrical sensor (electrode) is placed on each eye.
The probes that rest on your eye may feel a little scratchy.
This test is done to detect disorders of the retina.

The following conditions may cause abnormal results: - Arteriosclerosis with damage to the retina - Congenital night blindness - Congenital retinoschisis (splitting of the retinal layers) - Giant cell arteritis - Medicines (chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine) - Mucopolysaccharidosis - Retinal detachment - Rod-cone dystrophy (retinitis pigmentosa) - Trauma - Vitamin A deficiency
